
## Load Packages and Data

```{r load-packages, include = FALSE}
# install.packages("tidyverse")
# install.packages("broom")
# install.packages("readr")
# install.packages("ggplot2")
# install.packages("dplyr")
# install.packages("lubridate")

library(tidyverse)
library(broom)
library(readr)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
```

```{r add-observation-year-column}
salamanders <- salamanders %>% 
  mutate(date = as.Date(date, format = "%m/%d/%Y")) %>% 
  mutate(year = lubridate::year(date))
```

```{r create-range-object-for-range-analysis}
range <- salamanders %>%
  filter(pit != "none",
         pit != "not scanned",
         pit != "unknown") %>%
  group_by(pit, year, sex) %>%
  count(pool) %>%
  arrange(pit) %>%
  mutate(range = length(pool)) %>% 
  select(pit, year, sex, range) %>% 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    pit == "243206" ~ "m",
    pit == "243207" ~ "m",
    pit == "243209" ~ "m",
    pit == "243210" ~ "m",
```

```{r remove-duplicate-rows}
range <- distinct(range)
```


To date there have been 249 unique PIT tags deployed within the Otter Point population of salamanders. Below I ran some code to see which PIT tags, if any, had multiple years/colors associated with them. Out of 249 PIT tags, 46 are associated with more than one year (first year observed/marked)/color. 


## Sex 

```{r make-year-column}
salamanders %>% 
  mutate(year = str_extract(date, {"/dddd"}))
```

```{r histogram-sex-range}
range %>% 
  ggplot(aes(range)) +
  geom_bar() +
  facet_wrap(~ year)
```

```{r count-total-sexed-pits}
total=unique(range$pit[range$sex=="m"])
length(total)

total=unique(range$pit[range$sex=="f"])
length(total)
```

```{r slice-first-range}
sex_range <- range %>% 
  filter(sex == "m" |
         sex == "f") %>% 
  group_by(pit) %>% 
  slice_head()
```

### Analysis

```{r sex-range-wilcox-mf-all-years}
par(mfrow=c(3,1))
hist(sex_range$range[sex_range$year=="2022"])
hist(sex_range$range[sex_range$year=="2023"])
hist(sex_range$range[sex_range$year=="2024"])

par(mfrow=c(2,1))
hist(sex_range$range[sex_range$sex=="m"])
hist(sex_range$range[sex_range$sex=="f"])

boxplot(sex_range$range~sex_range$sex, ylab="range", xlab="sex")

wilcox.test(range~sex,data=sex_range)
```
